neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. neutral_message: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: I like it\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I do like it

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Do you dislike watching football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Why do you dislike watching football/

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Which team do you support?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What team do you support?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you watch football on TV?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Do you ever watch football on TV

Here is an example sentence written without any style: They are near the top of the Premier League.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes they are near the top of the Premier league.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I cannot get tickets, but I watch on TV frequently.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I cannot get tickets, but I watch on TV a lot.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is exciting to watch the games and cheer on your team to win.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Its exciting to watch the games and cheer on your team to win.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you watch any games?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Do you watch any games at all?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: They do that often.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes they do that often.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It can also be exciting. Do you watch your National team?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Sometimes, it is also exciting. Do you watch your National team?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I do not watch rugby.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I dont really watch rugby.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I do not go because it is impossible to get tickets, but I watch on TV often and it is exciting.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I dont go because its impossible to get tickets, but I watch on TV often and its exciting.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is easier when it is not the Premier League.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: yes its easier when its not premier league.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is a good sport that is entertaining and exciting.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes its a good sport, that is entertaining and exciting. How about you?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you support a team?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: do you support a team?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Sometimes after school, I like to score goals.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes sometimes after school. I like to score goals.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Are you not watching live?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: not watch live?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you enjoy watching football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Do you like watching football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you watch the games in person?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Do you watch the games in person?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The Sheffield United fan was a big fan of the team and could name previous players.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I think the Sheffield United fan was clearly a big fan of the team and could name previous players.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The fluffy cat was very knowledgeable about Sheffield United, which made it seem most genuine.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I think fluffy cat was very knowledgeable about Sheffield United and thats the one I think was most genuine.


\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Hello dreamy sloth.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hey dreamy sloth

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.\n\nI'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.\n\nI also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!\n\nWhy not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based? }\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Hello dreamy sloth.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hey dreamy sloth

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Are you there, dreamy sloth?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Dreamy sloth are you there?

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Hello dreamy sloth.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hey dreamy sloth

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
llm_tst:
{
  "rewritten_sentence": "Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week :) 

I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. 

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! 

What about you, have you checked if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?",
  "explanation": "I've added a smiley face emoticon to match person X's style and changed 'Why not see if' to 'What about you, have you checked if' to better fit the conversational tone and use of phrases that person X prefers."
}

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

  "rewritten_sentence": "Hi.. thanks for following along for the first week..
i'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. some of my favorite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part..
i also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. it looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?",
  "explanation": "The text was rewritten to match person X's conversational style by including their use of lowercase letters, specific phrasing like 'Hi..' and 'i also see', and the use of ellipses to mimic their informal tone. Additionally, the text maintains the original content and stays within the +-25% length constraint."
}
query:
You are an expert in text style transfer. You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,
and the corresponding sentences written without any style.
Your task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.

The text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.

For conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. 
 Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). 
Return results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""}

Here is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based? }
Here is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: I love Chelsea.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hello.i love Chelsea

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: I do not like football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: No , I like football

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.\n\nI'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.\n\nI also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!\n\nWhy not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based? }\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: What is your favorite team?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: what is your favourite team Funky panda

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.\n\nI'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.\n\nI also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!\n\nWhy not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based? }\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat—it's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: What do you like particularly in football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What do you like in football particularly?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Is it a hard question?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Is it a hard question?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: What do you like about football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hi what is particular do you like about football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is an interesting sport.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: It is an intersting sport

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you like football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Why do you like football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: There are more than two players that run after the ball.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: You do know they are more then 2 players that run after the ball?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: That is a good answer.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Thats a good answer

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.\n\nA year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.\n\nStay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.\n\nI'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is boring.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: it is boring

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.\n\nA year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.\n\nStay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You are an expert in text style transfer. You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is boring.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: it is boring

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is boring.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: it is boring

neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.
